reviewText: This new Opus Arte release from Holland is valuable for the Dutch soprano,Eva-Marie Westbroek. At last a Minnie who is truly up to the demands (and they are plentiful) of the role. She shirks nothing and delivers the goods. She not only sings well, but is dramatically involved and committed to a libretto/text that frequently is risible. She meets it on its own terms and rewards us with a performance that is not likely to be bettered in the near future.There are three other DVD Fanciullas in the catalogue: ROH with Domingo and Neblett, La Scala with Domingo and Zampieri and the Met with Domingo and Daniels. Domingo clearly loved the role; he sang it well and because it did not make the demands, say, of Arrigo or Aeneus he couuld retain it in his repertoire as he grew older and not have to compromise it as he did with Chenier. But what of the Minnies? Neblett does deliver a good performance but she was young and much of what happened to her in the following years was seriously compromised; I first heard her with the NYCO on one of its visits to LA in Mephistofele in which she sang Marguerite/Elena. The latter role has been sung by  spintos but it is short and with a considerate conductor the demands can be met by a lyric which is clearly where Neblett belonged. Her performance history in the years that followed was very spotty and erratic; another voice sacrificed for a career in a fach that could never be hers. Zampieri probably had more ammunition for the role, but one had to endure a manner of singing that was most peculiar, vibratoless and somewhat hooty, plus a rather peculiar stage presence. Daniels was another lyric who simmply waded out of her depth. I believe she no longer sings.Westbroek is an extraordinary singer. Her "Lady Macbeth" (Shostakovich, not Verdi) is one of the most riveting performances I have ever seen and heard. It didn't occur to me that she would find Italian roles that congenial but her Minnie is all that you could ask for. The voice is warm, Italianate and idiomatic. Her high C in Laggiu nel soledad is as stunning as Nilsson's and her middle voice is up to the demands of the role. Puccini is frequently in a conversational mode and she is able to meet this challenge as well. She is already the best Sieglinde around and I have no doubt that she would be a wonderful Elizabeth and Elsa.But what of her colleagues? Lucio Gallo, Jack Rance, is a baritone I first heard (via a VHS tape)as Figaro in Mozart's Nozze di Figaro from Vienna; slender, youthful he possessed a beautiful lyric baritone voice, he seems to have emerged as a dramatic baritone--or so he would like us to believe. A number of reviews have been anything but laudatory; indeed, some of them have been highly ceritical. A quick trip to YouTube and you can find a clip of Die Frist ist um! Interesting aspirations for an Italian. He manages the role of Rance though he could never challenge Macneil's Minnie dalla mia casa and I would not want to hear him as Scarpia. And what of our tenor, the Serbian Zoran Todorovich? The name was familiar but didn't remember why until I checked Amazon and found a surprising number of performances, ranging from Pollione (?) to Cavaradossi; many of the reviews were less than charitable. He possesses a stong spinto slightly baritonal tenor and a very short top. The role of Dick Johnson doesn't make many demands in that area and because he is slender and a fairly good actor I suppose the role can be considered apt. The problem is that when the vocal line ascends the voice starts to lack resonance and clearly this is a weakness that should have been solved years ago. By the time we get to the big aria he is able to deliver a reasonable faacsimile but will never efface memories of Bjoerling's many recordings of the aria.The production is far more troubling than the singing. The regie is Lenhoff who usually labors in different operatic waters, e.g., Wagner, spinning peculiar takes on the likes of Parsifal, Tannhauser and Tristan. In some cases they work and some cases they  don't. It has generally been assumed that one of the reasons this opera has never been as popular as Puccini's "canonic" three is the libretto. The source is a play of no literary distinction. Americans have been exposed to the wild west through Hollywood and hundreds of westerns although the genre has lost much of its appeal. In Europe it is slightly more exotic, but American culture is pervasive and even there the opera has had few revivals. I suspect the problem lies more in the difficulty of finding a singing actress who can deliver the goods. Here, Lenhoff's penchant for updating (it seems to be a leitmotif for him) makes even less sense than usual. The Polka resembles a gay leather bar. Minnie's "cabin" is all in pink; the third act looks a wrecked car facility although the lighting here is very dim so that one really can't be sure. I will have to admit that I find Lenhoff's final coup wonderful: when Minnie arrives to save Dick Johnson what wasn't visible was a stairway and Minnie appears quite glamourous in a red gown and her hair a short chic bob--right out of a thirties movie and behind her is the MGM logo; when Johnson reappears after all her appeals to the men he is dressed in a tuxedo!I suppose it can be aruges that we aren't dealing with a masterpiece, but musically I find the score to be one of Puccini's best and most sophisticated. Ideally one could wish that his literary sensibilities matched his growing maturity as a composer. That he could respond to a play in a language he couldn't understand does make a statement about the man. Unlike Strauss he didn't have his Hofmannsthal and he needed material that he could respond to. Surprisingly Belasco could provide whatever it was that ignited the creative spark.
summary: A Thrilling Minnie; A Less than Thrilling Production
Title: N/A

reviewText: This "review" refers to the OpusArte production of La Fanciulla del West, with Eva-Maria Westbroek.This DVD (DVD, not Blu-ray) was given to me for Christmas.  I tried to watch it several times:  every time, I was able to see the picture, with subtitles in several languages, but without any sound.  I skipped from chapter to chapter through Act 1 and part of Act 2:  no sound anywhere.I do not know where my son bought it, and I do not intend to tell him it does not work.  Five years ago, he gave me another Fanciulla del West (with Placido Domingo and Maria Zampieri), which I just watched with the greatest pleasure.  I notice however, that the OpusArte DVD sells on Amazon at a considerable discount; my advice:  don't buy it.  The Blu-ray disc, not discounted, is probably OK.UPDATE, OCTOBER 2013:  I just found out that this DVD (marked "All Regions") will play correctly on a zone-2 player.  It still does not work on my Blu-Ray player (picture OK, no sound).  I have not watched it yet, so I will leave the rating "as is".SECOND UPDATE, NOVEMBER 30,2013:  I have watched it now and it will go straight to the public library's donation bin, with a warning that it may not work on all players. One star? -- no, zero star if I could.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ... to a production of an opera I don't like?{Hold it now, pardner, put your six-gun away! Yes, I confess, I watched/listened to a DVD of an opera I don't much respect, productions of which I've previously panned. Hey, I love to be proven wrong! It validates my childhood. And I have a certain professional curiosity about all sorts of music... }No, I don't respect La Fanciulla del West, neither as theater nor as music. The libretto is bathetic melodrama, written to the taste of bourgeois audiences born fifty or more years before its 1910 premiere, podgy old coots and their trophy clothes-horse wives. The plot is so corny that John Wayne would have spurned a fat contact to act in it. The music is meandering romantic bombast, one trick of orchestration after another, all baton and no score. So there! So, as I asked before, how can I do justice to a production of it?Shall I say that the singing was mighty fine? It was. Zoran Todorovich brought sincere majesty to the 'voice' of "Mr. Johnson", actually the love-struck bandit Ramerrez. Lucio Gallo brought snarly vocal elegance to the role of the evil Good Guy, Sheriff Jack Vance. Both of them looked and acted their roles perfectly. Eva-Maria Westbroek looked too old for her role as the virginal Minnie -- that's the risk of Hollywood cinematography applied to a live opera production -- but she carried wood as an actress anyway, and she sang at least as well as the music deserved. Understand, please, that my expectations are not extreme for singers of this repertoire. None of them should ever be hired to sing Mozart or Monteverdi.Shall I compliment the Netherlands Philharmonic Orchestra and its conductor Carlo Rizzi? Okay, kudos to them! They did what they could.Shall I praise the costumers and set designers? There I can be sincere. The sets were sublimely silly, in keeping with the hokey libretto and the schmaltzy music. The first act is set in a gaudy 20th C Nevada casino... not Vegas or Reno, more likely Tonopah or Winnemucca. The second act takes place in a house-trailer with embossed pink walls and with an illuminated statuette of Ou Lady of Guadalupe flickering in the background. Minnie's faithful Amerindian companions grunt 'how how' like Tonto to the Lone Ranger, but in Italian. Amusing, no doubt, for that audience of 1910, but also disgustingly condescending. The third act ... well, perhaps I should let "you" be surprised by it. I'll just say that it takes place in an automobile wrecking yard.But that "concept" of La Fanciulla del West as a gigantic spoof of itself and of the mythic American West is exactly what I do like about this DVD. It's delightfully disrespectful! Can anyone doubt that Stage Director Nikolaus Lehnhoff and Set Designer Raimund Bauer felt more or less as ambiguous about the worth of this opera as I do? They've made a joke of it behind the backs of the singers and instrumentalists, especially the latter, those poor sods paid to play whatever gunk gets spread on their stands.Ah, sacrilege! The most dependable sort of humor.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love this opera and do not subscribe to the view that it is one of Puccini's lesser works. Yes the story is a bit improbable and the libretto these days is very dated, but taken in the right spirit it can be a lovely experience. The previous videos with Domingo and the old Tebaldi CD are great but of course not Blu-ray!This release is a big disappointment largely due to the wierd production. Act III is just ridiculous and negates some of the more interesting effects in Acts I and II. What might be a bit of fun ONCE in the opera house must never be allowed to interfere with the need for a Blu-ray recording to be suitable for repeat performances and Opus Arte have made a number of very bad blunders in this regard with some of their recent releases. The singing and acting is good to very good but the Domingo and Tebaldi ghosts are always there to remind one how well this opera can be performed. This does not quite match their peaks despite a very good audio recording. The picture quality is too dark in act I and III but fine in the bordello like scene in act II. What ruins this is act III with its over-the-top transition to Broadway. I cannot recommend this disc which is a shame as it may be a long time before we get another.
summary: Well sung and played but what a production!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I haven't so much as blinked at some modernised productions of operas set in the most unlikely of environments, but somehow I've never been able to get my head around the idea of an opera set in the Wild West - and yet that's the original setting for Puccini's La Fanciulla del West.  So if the Nederlandse Opera want to update the theme of the quest for gold conflated with the treasure of a virginal young woman into the more modern-day setting of Wall Street (references to pickaxes, mines and Wells Fargo notwithstanding), well, in principle, that's fine by me - there's no reason why, with a bit of invention and imagination, that shouldn't work ...and even if the opera opens in what looks like a leather gay bar, well, you know, I wouldn't necessarily see that as unlikely in this Puccini opera, particularly when Johnson makes his entrance among all those rugged men at the Pink Flamingo (I think it's called that) asking who is going to curl his hair... And wait until you see the set for Act 2!  There's more camp here than a Red Indian Reservation.La Fancuilla del West isn't ever going to be considered one of Puccini's best operas.  It's not his most memorable composition and with a subject that seems better suited to a Rogers and Hammerstein musical, it doesn't lend itself to the same highs and lows of love, passion and betrayal that you'll find in Madama Butterfly, La Bohème or Tosca.  It certainly doesn't seem to be the best vehicle for the seriousness of purpose of the composer towards adapting to new modern styles of composition.  The Rogers and Hammerstein comparison isn't really fair however (and a bit snobbish), nor is the criticism that Puccini has abandoned the beautiful melodies of his former work.  And if this production, conducted by Carlo Rizzi and directed for the stage by Nicholaus Lehnhoff, brings out anything, it's the qualities of the score and the varieties of tone that have a delicacy that belies the rather crude narrative and unimaginative storyline.As for the production, well, I'm afraid it just doesn't work.  If the director had really been committed to going for the Wall Street idea and really set it in modern financial district locations, the production might have been pulled it off (as Michael Haneke did with his production of Don Giovanni for the Paris Opera a few years ago), but this staging is half-hearted and uncommitted, a widescreen Technicolor tribute to Americana that has little rhyme or reason, resulting in the usual hodge-podge of anachronisms.  It's already a Western - how much more American does it really need to be?  The playing however is fine and the singing generally good, Eva-Maria Westbroek demonstrating the qualities that Puccini manages to bring to the role of Minnie.The image quality of Opus Arte's Blu-ray release isn't as impressive as other HD presentations, the bold coloured lighting not allowing a lot of detail to be shown, but there are no real issues with the transfer either.  Much more important, and where opera on Blu-ray really excels, is in the High Definition audio.  Here, there's a DTS HD Master Audio in a 5.0 mix and a PCM stereo track.  Both are a little harsh and over-dynamic and it's hard to find the right volume level - too loud and it's booming, too low and the singing is inaudible.  There is a happy medium however, if you can find it, where the qualities of the performance can be heard.  Overall, this is a good performance of La Fancuilla del West and the stage production is nice to look at, but it doesn't really bring anything new out of the opera.
summary: Mixed production of an underrated opera

reviewText: This production is disgusting.  An absurd take on such a simple story.  It is also horribly sung by all the principles, especially that of the soprano.I'm giving it one star because Amazon requires at least the lowest rating.  The producing team completely works against the libretto.  There are many instances where the text cvompletely conficts with what is onstage.There is NOTHING of value in this DVD.

reviewText: La Fanciulla Del West is Giacomo Puccini's Western.  This production, featuring Eva-Maria Westbroek, Lucio Gallo, Zoran Todorovich, the Netherlands Philharmonic Orchestra, and the Chorus of De Nederlandse Opera is entertaining from start to finish.  The sets have a more modern feel to them than a more stereotypical Western staging of the production, but they work - particularly the very pink set that Act II takes place in.  Ms. Westbroek makes the transition from simple girl and emotional innocent to the more complex woman in love with a villain and determined to build a life with him.  You can see her Minnie wrestle with the situation and make the choice that is right for her, as Minnie realigns her inner self with the reality of what her head and heart tell her that she must do.  Lucio Gallo, who plays Sheriff Jack Rance, brings a depth to the character that makes him much more than the caricature that many choose to play here.  Mr. Gallo's voice is well suited to vocal demands of the role, and his performance gives Ms. Westbroek that much more to work with.  Zoran Todorovich does a fine job in the role of Dick Johnson, and is very believable as he falls for Minnie and chooses to change his ways.With respect to the music itself, the Netherlands Philharmonic does a similarly fine job bringing the music to life, and freeing the performers to jump whole-heartedly into their roles.  And the chorus is rock solid.  As for the DVD itself, it contains a "Backstate insights" feature that is fun to watch and helps give some perspective to what goes on behind the curtain - and how important the efforts of all involved are.  This is a very enjoyable production of this Opera, and I thoroughly enjoyed it from start to finish.
Title: N/A
